Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the proximity of the hurricane to the migrant caravan by stating that it is "headed directly toward" their path, when in fact the projected landfall is over 1,000 miles north of their current location.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that the hurricane will directly impact the migrant caravan. The weather advisories do not extend to the town where the caravan is currently located.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the caravan will eventually cross the path of the hurricane, but it is uncertain if they will actually do so. The caravan may choose a different route or direction.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the potential impact of the hurricane on the caravan. The post suggests that as the caravan heads north, they may encounter deteriorating conditions from the hurricane, but it does not guarantee a direct hit.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the number of people in the caravan is lower than the 10,000 claimed in the headline. Reports estimate the number to be around 7,000.
Falters at times: The claim falters by using an outdated link to support its argument, even though the latest updates on weather.com suggest a different landfall location for the hurricane.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the claim.
